comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Unchanged in StreetView.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Most useless dating evidence ever: in 1880 Mortimer's Plymouth Dyeing Works had already been established for 106 years, according to this advert in The Royal Cornwall Gazette Falmouth Packet, Cornish Weekly News, & General Advertiser (Truro, England), Friday, October 22, 1880

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Here is the OS 25" map surveyed in 1898. The DIA says the National Bank (now BofI) is from 1866.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: And in the interest of balance, from The Dundee Courier & Argus (Dundee, Scotland), Saturday, August 15, 1896: and from The Yorkshire Herald, and The York Herald (York, England), Monday, November 04, 1895 Thomson's Dye Works sign

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: 1901 census, Main Street: McCarthy is there, but no Gaynor, FitzGibbon, Corkery, or Curtin. There is a Dore, but a boarder and shop assistant, not a shopkeeper. 1911 Census, Main Street: James McCarthy is dead, but his widow Margaret is still in business. David Hartigan, shopkeeper, has a 10 year old stepson named Jerry Curtin. James Cahill has a 4 year old stepson named Cornelius Dore.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: No Gaynors at all in Rathkeale 1901, but there is a family in Well Lane (around the corner) by 1911 - not shopkeepers though, Patrick is an RIC pensioner, and his eldest daughter a teacher. I'm beginning to think this photo is after 1911 - nearer the 1914 cut-off.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: in 1911, Kate Fitzgibbon is 24, a Seamstress, boarding in a house on the Square.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Or perhaps the photo is from a generation earlier?

comment.author: 30687643@N00
comment._content: Its amazing, the shop fronts on the left above the bank have hardly changed! Its living history, should they be protected?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The woman in the pale dress is wearing her hemline just below the knee; That'd be early 20s, I think (or 40's)

comment.author: 8468254@N02
47290943@N03
comment._content: This is a Lawrence Collection photo [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02], so the very latest date possible is 1914...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Well you've got an interesting anachronism in it then.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Maybe the shop on the left behind the streetlight (and the two gents in hats) is not Corkery, but Chris Corneille, Tobacconist, Ironmonger and Hardware Dealer, Oil & Colourman?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: McSweeneys and Hayes are both common in 1901 and 1911, including many shopkeepers. Not much help.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: If you browse the census for 1911 you get a matching run of surnames for houses 10 to 13 and possibly 14 on the right hand side of the road www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1911/Limerick/Rathke... (Note house numbers are census numbers not street numbers) Corneille is further down the list but the other names don't match for the left hand side. EDIT: No such matches in 1901 so presumably this photo is closer to 1911 than 1901

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] Yes, but the Dore and Curtin are 10 and 4 years old, stepchildren of the shopkeepers.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] The shopkeepers could have married the widows of previous proprietors.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] 10 years is sufficient time for the 28 year old Robert Dore to set up shop, marry Mary, father a son, Cornelius, and pass away and for Mary to remarry James Cahill who takes over running the shop by 1911.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Very happy to change this to circa 1911, especially given the high Lawrence glass plate number - 9083...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: These seem to be mostly long-established local names: here is a directory from 1846 showing a FitzGibbon, Dore, Hickey, and Hayes on Main Street, and McCarthy on the Square. So while 1911 does seem reasonable, these names do not rule out a date of say 1885, the generation before the census of 1901. If this is as late as 1911, I'd expect someone to be selling Pratt's Motor Spirit! There is another similar shot with an interesting ad which looks like a six-pointed star at the extreme right, but it is illegible in the lo-res version.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Look what I found just below the Chinaman, above the lady with the controversial hemline: Depot for Fleet Bicycles I think Fleet Bicycles makes 1911 much more likely!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: One possibility for that females scandalously high hemline: she may not be an adult. If she was a 12 year old with a little sister of 5, that might explain it.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] That "six-pointed star" could be a picture of the pelt of an animal - perhaps a rug?

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: On a separate matter - some of you may enjoy this interactive bird's eye view of Dublin from 1890 maps.bpl.org/id/10881

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I agree on the hemline. Think it's a girl rather than a woman in the "scandalously high hemline"...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
